meta.title: Should I focus this blog on one topic? - 17. jan 2022

title: Should I focus this blog on one topic? - 17. jan 2022
Web3
b
. I am already half-deep into the waters here, and will probably join an early stage web3 startup shortly.
Right now I am thinking of what to do next. There are multiple things I think I could be good at, and go deep into:
Video encoding and streaming
b
. I made fileparty.co and videofly.io, and realize I have a little guilty pleasure for video encoding technology. It fascinates me. I could dive deep into this.
I'm thinking of a description like this:

"This website is a chaotic place for my thoughts, projects and writings. It is not centered around one topic, but rather a conglemeration of my articles, short notes and random ideas. It is like my brain: some good parts, some messy parts, and all in all a huge interconnected web of interesting topics and creative ideas".
b

It makes sense to focus on one thing, but at the same time, larskarbo.no is a website about me, and I'm a complex creature with lots of different interests. Maybe I could focus more on one topic on Twitter, and keep this place messy and chaotic?

Right now this blog is a about many things. I am all over the place. Indie hacking, bootstrapping, productivity, web3. I think this is ok for now, but it might be more powerful to focus on one thing. Then people know what to expect and I can spend one or two years going deep into it.
Indie hacking or bootstrapping
b
. Much like my writings in 2021 about my
12 startups in 12 months
a
/1ae94a0ff4d8414baf15bf71f3b0f149
project.
Or maybe my blog should just be chaotic?
Should the blog be focused around one topic?
There is a power in focusing on one thing. You can start blogging about that topic, you can become an expert in that topic.

meta.description: Imitate is the most successful project I have done so far. It is a web-app for practicing French pronunciation with the use of random YouTube segments.
meta.title: Launching Imitate

title: After launching I ended up with 1500 email subscribers, got more than 200 Google Form feedback submissions, and 150 email feedback replies.
I knocked down my third launch, and am super happy to still be on schedule for the system.
Imitate was an exciting project, and is the most profitable I have had so far. Mostly because of my lucky shoutout on a big newsletter, but also my ability to capitalize on a situation.
Imitate is the most successful project I have done so far. It is a web-app for practicing French pronunciation with the use of random YouTube segments.
His newsletter had over 70K subscribers, and he wanted to give Imitate a shoutout.
I can always go and do another iteration when I have time.
When I had something that worked (ish), I sent it out to the people who had pre-ordered.
Wow, this took longer time than expected.

I decided I would make a paid add-on to Imitate. A paid french pronunciation course. It’s smart to sell before you make, so I put out a pre-order page and sent it out to all email subscribers. After two emails I had over 40 sales. Awesome.
I feel guilty, but it’s also an important learning experience.
The 12 startups in 12 months challenge forces you to move on to your next project. This can mean leavning unrealized potential and momentum, or letting fires burn.
I felt great, and motivation surged.
Imitate is a web-app for practicing French pronunciation with the use of random YouTube segments.
This is the most successful project I have done so far.
To capitalize on the situation I spent 2 weeks and created a paid course.
I hired a French native speaker to do some recordings with me.
I feel guilty about abandoning my users
Then I built the technical infrastructure.
😩 I barely finished the course, and haven’t gotten more time to work more on the project.
After a few days this ritual seemed a bit worthless.
I got only got a few subscribers every day.
b
A guy called Benjamin reached out to me. He had seen some of my tweets. Turns out he is the man behind
French Together
a
https://frenchtogether.com/
- a blog aimed and newsletter aimed at French learners. He is a part of the same
community
a
https://bloggingfordevs.com/
as me.

I hit my deadline, but I was exhausted. I did not have time or energy to promote the release or get more sales. I did not have time to properly support the users. I was already three weeks into february. I still had another launch I had to do in February.
I made waitlist subscribers my primary KPI, committed to post updates every day on twitter:
I decided to post updates on Twitter for my 1 week marketing sprint. Build in public. Create a huge following before launch. All of that.
I crunched through it. I didn’t have much time. I was already way past schedule. I worked around the clock the last couple of days.
Benjamin posted about Imitate on on a monday, and I immediately got a surge of new users on the site.
Be able to say: “This is good enough”, “This was the best I could do”. And then move on.
I pre-sold 50 copies of the course for 12$ each. That’s 600$. 💰💰
I got 70K people to hear about my project
I felt the need to capitalize on the situation and momentum I had.
12 startups in 12 months is brutal, I had excactly 5 days left of February, and I needed to make a new product.
I earned 600$ as a French teacher
After shipping the last Imitate update, I haven’t even checked and responded to the feedback forms.

meta.title: The three Phases of Creating Useful Stuff on the Web

title: If you release it, big or small, you go on to
phase two ↓
b
You have this amazing idea. Maybe you think you’ll be able to finish it quickly.
The three Phases of Creating Useful Stuff on the Web
This model is solely based on the
build
i
aspect. It doesn’t mean the business parts aren’t important. Because they are.
Think small, and minimum viable product, to quickly move on to phase 2
You make a github repo and things start to take form.
Which phase do your projects usually end up in? Let me know in the comments.
Congratulations! You made something that is usable and valuable for people!
This is the phase where you start coding the project.
Sometimes, it is ok. If your idea wasn’t that good anyways.
When you start getting traction and people start to use your product, you move on to
phase 3 ↓
b
I have
a lot
i
of failed projects that never got out of phase one (at least 150), I have some things that I released, but never took it further. And I have a few successful projects.
I think it is important to learn that it might take more work before you find traction.

caption: me building a random idea I got
title: code2.png
After 157 failed projects I have started to figure out how and what to do to make my online creations successful.
This is the most common pitfall.
Recognize the phases and the common pitfalls and you will have an easier time building useful stuff on the web.
By recognizing these phases and thinking rationally about them we will become better at creating
successful projects
b
Business parts are important, but not included in this model
You’ll stay in phase two as long as you are still releasing and improving.
You start building something, never get to the point where you can share it.
You are probably thinking of something that is missing.
This model will make you more successful at creating useful stuff on the web.
Make sure to share this with anyone you think would like to hear it!
Some marketing and outreach might be necessary in this phase.
I
love
i
building and shipping new things. Sometimes I get extremely motivated in the beginnings.
The next step is harder. The step to take the creation and make it into something better. It requires iteration and hard work, and doesn’t give you instant gratification.
From here you can leave it, continue to work on it or start monetizing it.
I have a lot of failed projects that never got out of phase one
It is simple and easy to understand.
The idea didn’t
take off
i
, and you are unsure whether it’s any point in continuing.
Common pitfall #2: Lose motivation after first release
Your motivation is a bad indicator of whether you should work on something or not.

meta.title: I just launched my indie hacking career on TikTok

title: Here are the 4 reasons I’m doing this:
The core goal of this experiment isn’t TikTok in itself, it is Indie Hacking and building products.
I just posted my first TikTok in what might be a little
life-changing experiment
b
Slapper
b
is the idea I’m going to realize first. It is a platform where you can refer to songs from Youtube or Spotify and take notes on them. You can also refer to specific segments of the songs.
More on this soon on TikTok!
b
Feedback and early customers
b
. This is important when building stuff.
I just launched my indie hacking career on TikTok
Fantastic things can happen when you realize how fear of embarrassment can limit you, and you start working to remove it. The biggest barrier to success is yourself.
The story of why I expose myself on such a weird platform that nobody really understands.
Less lonely
b
. It can feel lonely to work on own projects for a long time. Show it to others and you’ll feel better.
If you are interested in following how this TikTok experiment goes, download the app and follow me:
tiktok.com/@larskarbo
a
https://www.tiktok.com/@larskarbo/
Accountability
b
. People will expect you to make progress and you will strive to deliver.
Indie hacking - or
independent hacking
b
- is the philosophy of building, shipping and selling products on your own. Popularized by people like
@pieterlevels
a
https://levels.io/
and made possible by innovations in the tech and dev space.
By putting your face and ideas out there, people will start to reach out. They will have you in their subconscious, and over time it will compound to more quality connections.
What is Indie Hacking. The plan and my 3 ideas:
If you are invisible in this modern age,
you don’t exist
b
TikTok might fail, but the format will persist.
whentime.is
b
is a url timezone utility I
think
i
can be useful, but I’m not sure. Imagine typing whentime.is/4pm-in-oslo to send a link to anyone in the world and they’ll get their local time at that time. Genius? Yes?
By putting your work out there and
building in public
a
https://growthhacklist.com/methods/build-in-public
, you will get some different advantages:
By taking this step in an uncomfortable space, I start the process of learning that
it doesn’t matter
i
. I’m not going to die. People will probably not care much. If it is bad, people will forget about it quickly.

The way we communicate will shift towards the trends we have seen with Snapchat, Instagram and now TikTok. Short, entertaining videos might be the core way to communicate in the future. Teens and young people are the first adopters, but it will soon ripple through to the rest of society too.
My ideas as you see in the TikTok:
Why I did it?
i
It is not random. It is a well planned thing, with some exciting predictable outcomes.
1. Tear down my own mental prison walls.
TikTok is a platform that supercharges creative expression. It is really fun.
The quality is a bit low, and it wasn’t as polished as I wanted, but that doesn’t matter. The system is the key, and starting imperfectly is way better than never starting.
I am going to post a new video like this
every day
b
for
at least a month
i
Feedback or thoughts about this whole thing are greatly appreciated. Send them wherever or on DM on
twitter
a
https://twitter.com/larskarbo
Most of the things we are afraid of are just inside our heads. Fear of embarrassment have stopped people from doing what they love for ages.

meta.title: The Art of Doing Small and Simple Projects

title: Is this a good idea? It might become one of my four last projects.
Simple projects is an art. Simplicity in general is an art. It can make a huge difference.
The Art of Doing Small and Simple Projects
I always knew it’s smart to not build everything yourself and to keep things simple. I just needed to feel it on my body.

When you aim to be fast and deliver lots of things the work can end up being shallow. Certain things needs to be on most projects (like a website, payment solution and user management), and after implementing that, it’s not much time left for the unique, interesting and deep work.
Investing in crypto might be smart for the future, but it takes space in your head.
I built my own auth system and thought it would make my life easier. But when email validation suddenly stops working on a project you did 4 months ago, I regret that decision.
This is cool. And it might help, but it doesn’t
solve
i
the problem.
The four last projects will be simple. I promise.
I know this exists for computers, but I want a simple keyboard on iOS.
When I started my 12 startups in 12 months project, I aspired towards freedom. But I realize, if you play your cards wrong, you'll just end up with less freedom and more liabilities.
And leave less space for important deep work.
Compansating by being a rock star developer
In my head, the holy grail of simple projects has manifested itself to be an API.
Simplifying means choosing less pieces to work with. Maybe you end up not needing that much optimization. Simplifying makes you life easier.
My usual response to these problems, have been to just double down on becoming a better, faster and more efficient programmer.
A lot of the work I end up doing is making UI. The same shit, over and over again.
I want at least two of the last four projects to be paid API endpoints. I’ll deploy them on RapidAPI, and have as few moving parts as possible.
Simple projects solve one thing very well.
But can’t you compensate by using premade components and being smart when developing?
What about a voice input keyboard that let’s you modify text, add punctuation and write a book?
Now I’m sitting with a bunch of products in my hands that need big new iterations to ever be successful.
Do people use dication on their phones? Speech-to-text is starting to be extremely good, but I find it hard to use dictation as a complete writing tool.
No UI, subscriptions or email integrations scripts to worry about. They won’t take my developer time, and – more importantly – they won’t take space in my head.
When I started my
12 startups in 12 months
a
/1ae94a0ff4d8414baf15bf71f3b0f149
project, I aspired towards freedom. But I realize, if you play your cards wrong, you’ll just end up with less freedom and more liabilities.
Becoming a better developer helps, because you
optimize
i
the process. Cut down time and energy required to build and maintain things. But it’s like having a budget, and reducing some of the budget costs.
Paving the way forward for my last 4 projects
I need to stop making complex products.
I have made 8 of the 12 startups. I will make four more things before 2022.
If I make and API and sell it on something like RapidAPI, I only have one piece to focus on. I can focus all my energy into this one piece.
I see this as a challenge. I componentize things, reuse code across projects, and over time decrease the complexity and work required to make things several places.
Simple Projects have one problem to solve

meta.title: Shutting down my side projects to find focus

title: I will shut down Slapper, Imitate, MediaChopper, VideoFly, and TokenBird, and I pause new development work with freelance clients (
Rude Boy's
a
https://rudeboys.io
and
Holo World
a
https://holoworld.io
For the new chapter of my life, I should rethink my strategy. Make sure that I don't drag over habits and patterns from the experiment that don't serve me anymore.
Shutting down my side projects to find focus
Oliver Burkeman’s book
4000 weeks
a
https://www.goodreads.com/en/book/show/54785515-four-thousand-weeks
hit me hard. I'm going to cultivate the
Joy of missing out
i
and seek to be intentional about where my focus and attention will go.
Why can't you keep XXX running? You don't need to do anything.
i
b
i
It’s easy to fall into the trap that you can have things running without interfering with your main attention. Things will take space in the mind.
I strive to be a human that is present with work, life, play, and the ecosystem around me. In order to do this, I need a simple life. That means developing a different attitude towards opportunities.
Multiple projects can give you the illusion of making progress when all it’s doing is giving you a reason to procrastinate from something hard.
I purposefully went out and started more things than I could maintain. I allowed myself to do things I knew weren't sustainable in the long term. Be contrarian to common advice.
I will be joining a company and working there for at least a year. I will go deep into this project. On the side of my main tasks, I will learn new relevant things, and interact with communities.

The most appealing way to resist the truth about your finite time is to initiate a large number of projects at once. You get to feel as though you’re keeping plenty of irons in the fire and making progress on all fronts. Instead, what usually ends up happening is that you make progress on no fronts—because
each time a project starts to feel difficult, or frightening, or boring, you can bounce off to a different one instead
h
yellow_background
. You get to preserve your sense of being in control of things, but at the cost of never finishing anything important.
- Oliver Burkeman, 4000 weeks
h
gray
This means changing the landing pages to goodbye pages, redirecting the domains, or closing them altogether. Forcibly shut them down.
Last year was all about generating opportunities. Saying yes to everything. Building a
new startup every month
a
/1ae94a0ff4d8414baf15bf71f3b0f149

meta.title: How should I design my blog?

title: Clean article view
b
. The article styling should make reading as easy as possible. The article design should be clean and user friendly. Don’t get in the way.

Design does not matter, but unique design and good content can make the site memorable. I have created a little corner of the internet now that I feel comfortable and at home in. Would love to write and create this space further now.
How custom should I do it?
My current blog is pretty simple and clear. But I want something more unique. Something that gives more of a “wow” and “weird” response.
How should I design my blog?

caption: The current blog design is clean, but I think it could be better and more unique.
title: Untitled
Icons.
b
I get inspired by Notion. The small icons next to articles gives them more life, and makes the whole thing feel more interactive, for some reason.
Some good examples are
Josh W Comeau
a
https://www.joshwcomeau.com/css/custom-css-reset/
and
Gwern
a
https://gwern.net
. They have excellent content and really thought-through, unique design.
Front page overview
b
. I’d like a nice way to show an overview over the content on the front page. Maybe I’ll make a organized web structure optimized for desktop screens? I’ll see.
Now I am ready to do some technical and design work. I feel I deserve it now. Finally I can dive into tweaking details and optimizing pages.
I am very happy that I spent my time writing content instead of procastinating on details like this since starting to write here. The last 18 months I have written 19 posts. Some have been good.
For example, it might be tempting to add structured data like
tags
i
or
icons
i
. But that means you need to support that for all articles you write in the future. The more work it takes to support that feature, the higher the likelyhood of the feature being discontinued.

As a general principle, I don’t think it’s important to focus on blog design. It’s just one of those things it’s easy to end up doing instead of writing. Actually writing. It’s so easy to spend all time and energy on finding the perfect framework, doing SEO optimizations and creating the right design. And then you never got to the writing part.
I think it is important to keep things simple and focus on the core data formats of a blog article.
How should I design my blog?

Good content + unique design = a brand people will remember. If the content is bad, a unique design will just make it worse. People will see that you are terrible at prioritizing. At the other hand: having excellent content and bad/boring design doesn’t matter. Like Paul Graham has.
If I make some custom funny animations, or custom components for my website, they will probably be replaced sometime in the future.

meta.description: The story about how I launched FileParty, and almost got my first B2B sale.
meta.title: Launching FileParty

title: Maybe I will get a realization after some time?
I did not earn any money on FileParty. That is not good. I need to start creating things I can sell.
For my next launch I will earn 100$ on launch day.
b
PS: I can’t tell you the name of the platform yet. (But it’s not Zoom.)

But another part of it is that I need to write better code. Need to be better at taking a step back and refactoring. Drawing system arcitecture on a piece of paper. Speed is important in the dev world, but if you never focus on the craft of quality code, you will never be fast.

I always start to question myself before launching. “Is this thing even useful?”. “It doesn’t work anyways”. Maybe it’s my mind trying to protect me from the irrational dangers of putting my work out there.
The story about how I launched FileParty, and almost got my first B2B sale.
So I sat down to do what I like the most. Building.
In my situation, choosing something to build was better than doing nothing. At least I would increase my chance of serendipitous encounters and observations by doing it.
I am happy with the launch. The feedback I get over time, and my coming weeks reflections will decide is FileParty will go on to evolve or be killed off.
I got the MVP up. Using Firebase, no authentication, trying to make it as simple as possible to test it out. I ended up using the amazing
WebTorrent
a
https://webtorrent.io/
library, which gives technology similar to BitTorrent just for the browser.
Maybe I will meet the right person that gets excited and leads FileParty the right way?
After stressing about finding a good idea for some days, I remembered something I have heard:
Having your schedule fully booked can be a disadvantage
i
. It gives you tunnel vision. Having some unstructured time can lead to discovering opportunities.

FileParty is full of bugs. There were bugs during development and there are bugs now. A lot of it comes from the fact that it is complex in nature, needing synchronization and relying on unstable external functions.

I never thought finding an idea would be a problem, because I have always had too many of them. This is the reason I quit my job and became a indie hacker in the first place. But now I was actually not sure what to make. It needed to be something good!
As usual before launch, I get this feeling of disgust over the project. Can’t stand it anymore. Just want it to be gone, over.

⬆️ Upvotes on ProductHunt: 221
👀 Visitors: 635
🔗 Boards created: 1073
💰 Revenue (donations): 0$
⏳ Time spent: 3 weeks

The unique parts of FileParty is the p2p technology. Since 2018, WebRTC has been stable in Chrome. This is why we can have video calls in browsers now without any plugins. However, when making a custom WebRTC app, there is still a lot of work needed to make it work reliably. One common problem is peer discovery. You need to find the IP adresses of other computers visiting the same site.

This idea was definetely “cool tech” more than it was “something the market needed”. I got interested in the tech, and made up a possible market need after. People say this approach is stupid, and you should identify user problems and then find a suitable solution. I get that. But I don’t want to listen to it. I think there are multiple ways to make a successful project. Sometimes you might need to tinker with the technology, experiment with things, trust your intuition before you find something that works in the market. At least that’s what I keep saying to myself.
So I relaxed, took a week off where I walked around, read, and drank coffee. Tried to talk to people. Just waiting for a good idea.
TLDR;
b
FileParty
a
https://fileparty.co/
is a real time file sharing service I hacked together and launched on Product Hunt. It got over 200 upvotes, but no revenue.
I had to do a new project in December. It’s part of my
12 startups in 12 months
a
/12-startups-12-months/
project where I launch a new startup every month.
What about a
high-quality replacement for screensharing
b

? Where you share the actual video file instead of sharing a recording of your screen. I thought this could be valuable for presenters and teachers in the remote world. If you want to show a video or audio file over Zoom today, it sounds terrible.
This is the story of how I found the idea, build it and launched it succesfully.
Maybe it gets randomly picked up and goes viral?
Then I read something about
WebRTC
a
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebRTC_API

. The web API that makes it possible to do video calls in the browser. It makes it possible to send data directly from one computer to another. Just like torrent technology, like we had on The Pirate Bay. Could there be something for me here?
Fuck that. I will launch things till I die.
On monday 28th December, I posted FileParty on Product Hunt, wrote the
twitter post
a
https://twitter.com/larskarbo/status/1343469561903984640
, and sent a note to on my
personal newsletter
a
/newsletter
. Then I took a step back and waited for the responses.

He was interested in integrating FileParty with their service. This was exciting, and excactly the kind of opportunity I hoped the launch would create. I am going to meet with him next week, and will let you know how it progresses.
I got more upvotes than ever before (
a
https://www.producthunt.com/posts/focusmonkey
a
https://www.producthunt.com/posts/slapper
), but didn’t get that much engagement. Upvotes and likes aren’t really important. I care about people that tested the product and sent me a message about it.
I’m not sure about the future of FileParty, so I will let serendipity and the unknown powers of the universe work on it for a while.
This idea was definetely “cool tech” more than it was “something the market needed”.

I have seen this in real life too. People get tired of a 5-year college degree right before it ends. People get tired of the 1-year military service right before it ends. I don’t know the psychological reasons for this, but I think it’s worth being aware of.
EDIT:
b
I almost sold it to them, but they pulled out of the deal in favor of a cloud storage provider.
Ok, so I had an idea for a product. Not the best, but time had passed so much –
I was already 10 days into the month
i
– so I felt the need to start.
The head of product of an interesting new video communication platform contacted me.
The launching muscle is getting stronger. Stay tuned for my next launch.

meta.title: Having three writing sections: articles, random thoughts and random logs - 17. Jan 2022

title: Should I focus this blog on one topic? - 17. jan 2022
Articles.
b
These are well-written, thoroughly researched articles, written for a public audience. Example:
p
af74fadd-24c3-4e17-a933-fea1da00744a
5257cf0b-8124-4419-87b6-815988437df5

Julian Shapiro talks about getting the wastewater out when you write. Just start writing, write something poorly first, don't judge yourself. After a while - when you have gotten the wastewater out - good writing will come out.
Random thoughts.
b
Internal thoughts, ideas, or questions. More like an inner dialouge. This can be bad. Maybe some of the posts will be raw material for an
article
i
. I shouldn’t surface these posts as much as the
articles
i
, but maybe some readers find them interesting. They should be timestamped to avoid conflicts if I make an
article
i
with the same name. Example:
p
03324020-6778-4180-8f0b-6cb30b51035e
5257cf0b-8124-4419-87b6-815988437df5
I want to write more quality stuff. I admire people who write well and get an audience around their ideas. At the same time, aiming for perfection can become a prison.
How should I design my blog?
I'm thinking of a system that lets me work on high-quality well-written articles
in addition to
i
habit-enforcing waste-water small writings and notes.
The random logs section might actually make most sense if you are working on a clear goal on a clear path. Like being an Indie Hacker and tracking MRR.
Having three writing sections: articles, random thoughts and random logs - 17. Jan 2022
I’ll start writing some
random thoughts
b
-articles (like this one), and see how that works. Maybe I’ll do
random logs
b
when I nail down a clear goal for this year.
Random logs.
b
These are like a diary. I don't try to focus them around a topic or make them interesting for the general public. In some cases, if I am working towards a goal, it can be interesting to follow.
Alex West
a
http://alexwest.co
has an interesting system for this, wehre he writes
daily logs
i
and consolidates them into
monthly reviews
i
and eventually into larger articles.
Here is the system I have been thinking of:
Helication - Doing Nothing as a Productivity Strategy
Over new years I have been rebuilding and
redesigning this blog
a
/305be4b12dbb4fb89f96fe56481487b3
. Where should I take this blog?

meta.description: I almost launched Case shortcut in five days but had to abort it.
meta.title: (almost) Launching Case Shortcut

title: App signing, notarization, sandboxing. Things like that. Not a chance.
I was able to piece together a Swift app in a couple of days. But learning the Apple bureaucracy? Not a chance.
I didn’t want any cross-platform electron bloatware for this simple utility app. So I had to learn Swift.
I almost launched Case shortcut in five days but had to abort it.
The app is called Case Shortcut, and lets you change case between UPPER, Title, lower, and all other cases.
The app signing didn’t work properly.
I had five days to build and launch this thing. I failed.
I couldn’t sell this. I postponed the launch.
Maybe I will find some time later and launch it.
So I went ahead and pieced together an MVP of Case Shortcut. Copy-pasting lots of things from Stack Overflow. I didn’t know what I was doing.

caption: Monica Lent saying my mac app didn't work
title: 2021-04-03-22-04-35.png
But I guess this is how it is.

caption: Screenshot of the Case Shortcut welcome screen
title: 2021-04-03-22-18-40.png

One problem I had was that I couldn’t figure out how to open a welcome screen for the app. Being pressed on time, I brought up my most creative hacker spirit and made the same window in a website instead.
The only way people could use Case Shortcut was by adjusting their Mac security settings. Like pirates do.
I was going to launch on Product Hunt Sunday morning.
I finished the MVP, made the fully functional landing page with Stripe integration. Everything was ready.
When you open Case Shortcut it opens
this page
a
https://caseshortcut.com/welcomescreen/
. Heheh, I feel evil.

meta.description: My first startup in my project is Slapper. I built, launched and monetized it in a month
meta.title: Launching Slapper

title: This is the first startup I launched in my
12 startups in 12 months
a
/12-startups-12-months/
project.
APIs are great, and building things by using other services is a lot of fun, but it also adds some uncertainty to the project.
The best would probably be if I had a dedicated dashboard to see how many new users I have gotten, how many of those made
slaps
i
, and in general what people are doing on the site.
Ads from Youtube don’t show up in Slapper. Sounds like a bad deal for Google.
In one month, I built and launched it. Here is my breakdown of it.
I did some
soft launching
i
in Instagram and my personal networks first.
PS: I have been working a lot on my December project, which I will be releasing very soon.
Or maybe I will suddenly meet someone that gives me a valuable insight for Slapper?
I did the first of my projects in November. It was very fun. The project is
Slapper
a
https://slapper.io/
For now, I am letting slapper float its own way. I am not shutting it down, because maybe it will suddenly mature and get picked up by some exciting institution or group of people.
Can I really monetize the app when using the Spotify API?

It is a weird feeling to stop working on a project right after you have gotten a lot of new users. I think Slapper would need 2-3 more months of work before it could be something sustainable and growing.
But when it comes to user behavior I feel pretty blind.
My first startup in my project is Slapper. I built, launched and monetized it in a month
The best launch I had, was the
post
a
https://www.reddit.com/r/edmproduction/comments/k12297/after_learning_music_production_for_a_while_i/
I made on reddit. I made the post in /r/edmproduction and people seemed to like the humble personal style of the post.
Then I launched on
ProductHunt
a
https://www.producthunt.com/posts/slapper
. It didn’t perform that well, but got a good amount of users.
I added a payment portal, but did not get any sales.
s
Will youtube suddenly disallow my domain for iframes?
For the future of Slapper, I have questions like this:
It is part of the learning process of this project. You just need to let it go.
Wow, I really didn’t optimize for getting sales. But now that I have one I feel a burst of energy. FEELS SO NICE!
EDIT: Just checked, I GOT ONE SALE!!
I have gotten some positive feedback from people. I found 5-6 potential power users that were really happy with it.
I feel like I know too little. I have a Google Analytics script, so I see the number of users, but I don’t really see or understand much else.

meta.description: How I struggle to find the right user segment for my app. There are 4 different types of people that like it for different reasons.
meta.title: Help! 4 different kinds of people like my app

title: I will trust my intuition and see which way the product goes. Hopefully I will find a way to make at least one of Peter, Elisa, Johanne and Alfred happy.
I now have
4 different user segments with 4 different needs
b
. Which one should I focus on? I call them Peter, Elisa, Johanne and Alfred. They all want to use my app for different things. And it makes me crazy.
Startup influencers often talk about how important it is to find your user segment.
i
Who are solving a problem for?
Figure out your niche
a
https://thebootstrappedfounder.com/finding-a-market-to-build-a-saas/
, they say. Find your customer segment, they say.
The app I am talking about is
Slapper
a
https://slapper.io/
- the first startup of my
12 startups in 12 months
a
https://larskarbo.no/12-startups-12-months/
challenge - but it’s probably a relevant problem for all kinds of apps and products.
Alfred uses Slapper for having Youtube and Spotify in the same playlist.
b
He doesn’t care much about the segments or notes. He’s just too tired of having to switch between streaming services to play his favourite songs
Or should I choose the most relevant usecase and double down on it?
Elisa uses Slapper for memorizing and organizing songs.
b
She also likes to share the collection with her friends or revisit it later. Sometimes she uses it professionally in music or art projects, and would like the UI to look a bit more beautiful.
You might also end up with your own Peters, Elisas, Johannes and Alfreds.
Help! 4 different kinds of people like my app
How I struggle to find the right user segment for my app. There are 4 different types of people that like it for different reasons.
I mean, look at them. This is what happens when I don’t listen to the startup gurus.
Peter uses Slapper to loop specific segments of a song when practicing.
b
He values speed, and doesn’t care about sharing collections with his friends.
I did not do that, and now I am stuck with the consequences.
Johanne uses Slapper for giving homework to students.
b

She is a music teacher. To be able to share it with students is key, and she would want to have much more space for adding notes and text. Preferably some kind of Google Docs but with Slapper integrated.
And don’t forget to follow my newsletter for updates.
The app I am talking about
Am I left trying to make one piece of software fit for 4 different people?
b
If you have suggestions or advice for Slapper or my
12 startups in 12 months
a
https://larskarbo.no/12-startups-12-months/
project, feel free to ping me on
Twitter
a
https://twitter.com/larskarbo
Monica told me to choose the ones that pay the most for it, but right now
I have exactly 0 premium plan sales
b
, so that’s kind of useless.

meta.title: I'm Shutting Down Slapper.io

title: Thanks to all the people supporting me on the journey, and especially to the two persons that bought the premium subscription!
Slapper was a complex product that tried to solve
multiple usecases
a
/4-customer-segments/
. I never found the
one
i
thing that I could focus on and solve in a good way, so I ended up solving a lot of things poorly.
Building the right kind of portfolio
Slapper.io was the first of my
12 startup in 12 months
a
/12-startups-12-months
project. I planned to keep all of the projects alive, but I changed my mind. Slapper has to die.

I am building a portfolio of small bets. I want to build projects that are timeless – that they will get better and stay relevant over time. So that I can come back and do little pieces of work, and they can bring me opportunities and revenue.
I enjoy building things that can live on and still be useful in 5 or 10 years. Slapper is not that kind of product.

The main reason for not keeping it alive and online is that it relies on too many 3rd party integrations. Slapper integrated with a (buggy) Spotify API and used iframes for YouTube. The YouTube integration was very unstable, and the Spotify integration was laggy and unpredictable.
Slapper wasn’t a good project for me, so I’m shutting it down now.

During the initial months of Slapper I managed to get two paying premium members. It feels a bit weird and wrong to shut down something that is actually bringing in money, but I guess that’s the kind of choices you have to make.
After 7 months on the internet, I have decided to shut down
Slapper.io
a
http://slapper.io/
. It is not the kind of project I want to have in my portfolio.
It also doesn’t have a lot of SEO content, and almost doesn’t bring in any traffic.

meta.description: A year ago I started an ambitious project to create build 12 profitable small businesses. Now, a year later, I have a bunch of learnings under my belt.
meta.title: A Year of Making Is Done

title: TokenBird
b
i
(CoinMarketCap for NFTs). NFT project tracker. Made together with two friends. Only lasted one day before I knew I would shut it down.
Napchart
b
a
https://napchart.com/
. Service I already made 5 years ago, 150 daily visitors. Monetized it by adding premium. Earned 613.51$ so far. Love this project no matter the money. Will keep running it.
TokenBird
b
i
(NFT API). Made to solve my own need when making NFT websites (
a
https://rudeboys.io/
a
https://holoworld.io/
). Already had me as a customer.
Launch House is a new take on traditional business accelerators and universities. In the new modern world, you can get all information online. The important thing to focus on is relationships.
This comment on HN resonated with me and left me a bit discouraged:

I’m still thinking of what to do next year, but I’ll probably continue working in the Web3 space. Maybe I’ll go all-in on TokenBird, or I’ll join another startup. I’ll focus on finding good people to work with and seek to be part of good communities.
MediaChopper
b
a
https://mediachopper.io/
. App to solve an extremely rare edge case in Davinci Resolve. No one ever used it.
Videofly
b
a
https://videofly.io/
. Video transformation on the fly. Currently only used by me on a bunch of my projects. Almost got some big NFT sites to use it, but almost doesn’t cut it.
Indie hacking is intristically lonely, other things are intristically not-lonely.
Even if you can build things quickly
(example: building an authentication system)
i
, you will end up having all that code to maintain months down the road.
FileParty
b
a
https://fileparty.co/
. (0$). This gets 40-50 daily visitors, but barely works. No monetization. I feel
watchparty.me
a
http://watchparty.me/
is better. Will probably shut down.
LarsList
b
a
https://larslist.org/
. List of people named Lars. Costs 5$ to add yourself. Earned 132.50$. The most fun project.

I guess this comment made me feel less unique. In dark times I start to question if the things I make even matter. It can be hard to feel like you build meaningful stuff when you only have a few weeks.
A year ago I started
12 startups in 12 months
a
https://larskarbo.no/12-startups-12-months/
, where I set out to build 12 profitable small businesses in 12 months.
I would rather celebrate a victory together with a group of friends or co-workers, than sitting alone with my stripe revenue and MRR numbers.
A Year of Making Is Done

Somewhere in between number 6 or 7 — when I still tried to maintain them all — I realized something about simplicity. When you have 7 projects you need to maintain and update regularly, you start to understand that things need to be simple to work.
A year ago I started an ambitious project to create build 12 profitable small businesses. Now, a year later, I have a bunch of learnings under my belt.
This experience made me realize how important community is. Having deep connections to people around you makes life so much more fun and meaningful.
I haven’t lost the appeal of building things, but a lot of the indie hacking appeal has left me.
This year has been a great experience. I am happy and proud of myself for finishing it.
In the last month of 2021 I had the pleasure of living with 20 other founders in Launch House in LA.
It seems like most people who have started similar projects stop after two or three. I am happy I finished them all.
Thanks to everyone who supported me on the way. Especially
Monica Lent
a
https://twitter.com/monicalent
12x group
a
https://12xstartup.com/
and everyone at
Launch House
a
https://launchhouse.co/
Most of the projects were scratching-my-own-itch problems that I could solve with a website or an app.
Slapper
b
a
https://slapper.io/
. Service to loop, and collect segments from Spotify and Youtube. Got 2 paying subscribers, earned 81.90$ in total. Shut it down.
Personate
b
a
https://personate.ai/
. AI video generation. Made together with
another lars
a
https://twitter.com/vagneslars
. Got a 7000$ B2B pilot client. Had traction but lost it. At the end of the day, the whole product (vision) felt spammy. Shut it down.
Case Shortcut
b
a
https://caseshortcut.com/
. Mac app for a global shortcut to change text case. Cost 5$. Nobody bought.
Imitate
b
a
https://goimitate.com/

. French Pronunciation method I made. Got shoutout on a newsletter. Upsold 25 for premium course access. Earned 624$. Stale ever since. I broke up with my French girlfriend and am therefore not motivated for French anymore. Shut down.
I spent 2-6 weeks on most of the projects, and aimlessly tried to maintain and improve them for some more months before getting overwhelmed and shutting them down.
The motivation behind it was to try as many ideas as possible and build the necessary skills for succeeding at creative passive income projects.
You can’t really talk about indie hacking without talking about life design.
TokenBird
b
a
https://tokenbird.io/
(NFT Marketplace). Third TokenBird pivot. Decentralized NFT marketplace. Got 3 ETH in presales for access to the platform. Still working on this. It has potential.

meta.title: I biked 4000 km alone to find myself. Don't repeat my mistakes!

title: Whether it’s business, travel, programming or building. I am going to adventure into new spaces.
My bike trip was a prototype for future endeavours.
Learning #1: Social connection is a human need
Learning #2: You won’t have free time
At this moment I realized that travelling for months along cars and noise isn’t ideal.
I am used to hiking in the Norwegian nature. Days with silence, fresh air, beautiful scenery. You get time to think and relax.
I daydreamed about everything I could get done while biking through europe:
Learning #1: Social connection is a human need
Learning #2: You won’t have free time
It’s raining. You don’t know where you are. You are biking on the side of a car road. Cars and trucks are schwooshing past.
The journey lasted 3 months, and I learnt 3 things on the way:

Before this trip I was surrounded by people all the time. I thought I was the kind of person who liked best to be alone. I thrived when I could get time for myself, so I thought it was the best idea to go on this solo trip.
Learning #3: There are better places to bike
I quickly realized that this was very over-ambitious. I spent most of my time on primary needs:
biking
b
finding food
b
finding a place to sleep
b
Most people were going to university or starting ordinary, boring jobs.
One evening I suddenly got this idea for what to do. I wanted to 🚴 bike to from Norway to Italy.
After a couple of days in Denmark, without talking to anyone, I realized that this wouldn’t work.
In the beginning I did not have a clear target for where to bike. I told people I was going to bike
somewhere
i

. Somewhere in Europe. Or Africa maybe. But people didn’t like the vague answers. I eventually settled on Italy. Having a clear goal is helpful both for you and the people that tries to understand you.
Some years ago, after high school finished, I tried to figure out what to do next.

Switzerland and Norway was the best. They had nice paths and roads for biking, and the exciting landscape makes it fun to bike. Completely flat landscapes are hard, because they don’t give you any dynamics.
This is a skill that I still find valuable today.
When I was younger I set out on a grand trip to bike from Norway to Italy. Here are some of the lessons I learned.
Build and interactive blog to show where I was and how much money I had left
I biked 4000 km alone to find myself. Don't repeat my mistakes!
This is not my last adventure

After this realization I started a conscious effort to make social connections. I began using couchsurfing, reached out to people on the way and positioned myself in places to meet people. I slowly learnt how to keep the social part of my brain happy, and find friends in unlikely places.
As opposed to many other forms of travel, when biking you spend most of your time
between cities
i
. It is not like you can make a base in a city for a week and then move on. You need to constantly move on. That makes it hard to find time, energy and places to get work done.
No matter how you think, without social connection your brain dies. It is a need, just like food, water and sleep.
Learning #3: There are better places to bike
Sometimes on this bike trip I asked myself: “why?“. Why bike along the road with cars when I could bike on beautiful mountain paths or hike in wild nature?
Build side projects that could turn into passive income streams
My plan was to take my bike, start biking, and not stop until I was in Italy.
I wanted to do something crazy.
I had a urge inside me to do something else. In fact do the opposite of what everyone else did. I wanted away.

meta.title: Helication - Doing Nothing as a Productivity Strategy

title: Take a virtual helicopter out of the trenches, and you will see opportunities, roads and possibillities you never knew existed.
Stay in the helicopter for some time. Your brain needs time to readjust and let go.
Working on details will give you tunnel vision. You should give your intuition the best chance possible to see the next opportunities.

caption: A Black Hawk with a shower inside. Is this the perfect setup for a Helication?
title: shower-helicopter.png

For me, coding can be an extremely mind focusing activity. Especially if I get frustrated when solving a problem. Before I know it, my head is buried deep into a problem space and I’m not able to be present and see external opportunities.
Work is like being in the trenches. Nowhere to hide, nowhere to relax. Always things to do, always problems to fix. The only way to get out is to be rescued by a helicopter.
It sounds weird, but sometimes the best thing to do is to
do nothing
i
. In periods of life when you are assessing your next opportunities, step away from things that keep you busy.
A Year of Making Is Done

During my Helication, I have had to accept to see things burn. There are applications with bugs, client websites with flaws, and people desperately needing my help to fix “small problems”. A strict “no” is the only thing that works here.

As you hang on to the rope on your way up, you will see more and more of the landscape around you. You will see how different the landscape, different objects, and movements connect and interact. Maybe you’ll see some things burning, and get an urge to jump down and fix it. Like an itch you shouldn’t scratch. Even further up you might see a great opportunity somewhere. The urge to jump down and start the new project is even stronger. But you need to hold on to the rope all the way up.
Helication - Doing Nothing as a Productivity Strategy

Well, I don't mean doing nothing like just staring at the wall. Forever. But at least for this in-between period I should do as little as possible. Some activities just take away too much of your grand-perspective, horizon, opportunity-seeking abilities. Some activities need to be forcibly shut down in a period like this.

Sometime, the only way to solve a problem is to get out and do something else. Your brain works differently when it is focused on something and when its not. This is why you so often get good ideas in the shower.
After finishing
12 startups in 12 months
a
/8711af9b325448b89b35f8d6be011914

, I was struck by one big question: "what the heck should I do now?" Choose one of the projects and go all-in? Find a company or startup to work for? As I was sitting nervously on my couch thinking about this newfound problem, I had a realization. The best thing might be to
do nothing
i

Taking a helication means properly retreating, regrouping and completely reassessing possible next steps in the periods between jobs. If you fail to take a proper break, there is a chance you never got out of your rabbit hole, and could therefore not see the opportunities you had.
I have a serious problem of always wanting to working on a bunch of small projects. Having multiple balls in the air has become my default.
I have found
interacting with
i
people
i

to be the ultimate horizon widening and opportunity generating mechanism. Ping your network, hang out with different people, talk to friends, host dinners. Interacting with people is a great way to discover different opportunities and feed your intuition with all kinds of new ideas and ways to look at things.
A Focused Mind don’t see Opportunities

meta.description: We just signed a deal with a company for a BIG B2B sale. I am so excited to see where this project leads.
meta.title: BREAKTHROUGH: My first B2B sale

title: The small sales motivated us to continue working but didn’t exactly pay our salaries.
We got a message from a big company in Norway. They wanted to explore the option of using our product to make educational videos.
I have never made any considerable amount of money. Money that I can use to live. It has all been symbolic sums.
I joined my first startup more than three years ago. Since then, I have been working on different startups and grinding away at many of my own projects.
We just signed an 8K$ contract with them.
Now it’s back to work and deliver what they paid for within three weeks.
I built
Personate
a
https://personate.ai/
in one month together with my co-founder Lars. (yes, another Lars).
But then one HUGE thing happened…
Eight dollars is enough for two coffees. Not bad for one month of work.
We just signed a deal with a company for a BIG B2B sale. I am so excited to see where this project leads.
The price was 4$, and we got three sales (including one refund). Hurray! Eight dollars in the bank.

meta.title: Making an Internet-Connected Mouse Trap

title: I will leave out the technical details and source code, but if you are interested
contact me
a
/now/
and I will show it.
If you live in a 100-year old house as I do, chances are big you have some mice walking around in the walls. To beat them once and for all, I am going to make an internet-connected mouse trap.
When running the code, we see it instantly on our iPhone:

To make the mouse trap smart, we connect it to an ESP32 microcontroller. This is a small and affordable internet-connected computer. It reads real-time sensor data and can send messages on the internet.

caption: Mouse trap chart showing mouse trap, Telegram and a phone
title: mouse-trap-telegram-phone.png

caption: All the parts for a connected mouse trap scrambled
title: parts.jpg
Let’s build a new version suitable for the 21st century.
Do you have a dumb thing in your house you would like to make smart?
The traditional mouse trap is boring. It doesn’t even have software updates.

caption: Wood block for the IoT mouse trap
title: wood-block.jpg

The traditional mouse trap works like this: You arm the trap, put some cheese on it, and wait. When the mouse comes for the cheese, the trap snaps a metal thing right over the mouse, leading to instant death.
There are multiple ways to send notifications to a phone. One of the quickest is to use an existing app. We choose to send messages through the messaging app Telegram.
It takes around 10 seconds before the notification shows up on the phone.
This invention shows that it’s possible to hack together impressing things in a short time. The world of IoT devices like the
ESP32
a
https://www.espressif.com/en/products/modules/esp32
and services like
Telegram
a
https://telegram.org/
make this possible.
It might not be the most useful thing in the world, but it’s fun!
Instructions on how to make an internet connected mouse trap that sends you a message whenever there is a dead mouse in the trap.
Time to test our creation. Didn’t find any mouse, so I’m using a banana instead.
For 100 years, the mice have reigned in this house, but now it’s time for revenge.
In the background, you can see that the LED lights up when the metal from the mouse trap touches the springs. Hurray!
Setting up the mouse trap to send notifications
We need to be able to read the state of the mouse trap. Either it’s on and armed, or it has snapped with a mouse inside. To make this possible, we turn the mouse trap into a button.
The mouse trap will be connected to a small computer, and will send a notification to your phone when the trap catches something.
We add some wires to two springs:
And a gif version of the action.
Using hot glue and screws we take it all together, and add a logo. Doesn’t it look beautiful?
To make this invention last as long as its predecessor, we’ll attach it to a big block of wood.
Transforming the mouse trap into a sensor
And attach them to the trap:

meta.title: AnkiBot - Telegram Bot to Record Sounds to Your Anki Collection

title: To run AnkiBot, you will need
Node.js
a
https://nodejs.org/en/
Yarn
a
https://yarnpkg.com/
and
ffmpeg
a
http://www.ffmpeg.org/
Make sure Anki is open, then run the script:
Multi-note smartness.
b
If you have the same word/sentence to be recorder on multiple notes, it will automatically add the sound to all notes.
In order to communicate with your Anki instance, AnkiBot uses
AnkiConnect
a
https://foosoft.net/projects/anki-connect/
Ankibot
b
is a Telegram bot to let anyone remotely record pronounciations for your Anki collection.
Perfect for outsourcing.
b
No need to split mp3s and work with audio manually. Just point your coach to the bot!
Access control.
b
To prevent abuse, you can specify which chat-ids you want to have access.
If you have ever used Anki for language learning, you know how important
native voice recordings
b
are.
Now go to your bot in Telegram and start recording by writing /start.
Create a new Telegram bot and retrieve the API Token. Use the
@botfather
b
bot.
You can also check out the repo here:
https://github.com/larskarbo/ankibot
a
https://github.com/larskarbo/ankibot
Follow the corresponding tutorials to install those, if you don't have them already.
Native voice recordings let you learn the sounds and how they correlate to written language.
Flexible api.
b
Define which notes you want to have recorded in
noteSpec.js
c
. Specify field, deck and card type.
In order for
AnkiBot
b
to know which cards you want to record sounds for, and which fields to fill in, you will need to populate the
noteSpecs.config.js
c
file.
Retry-possibility.
b

meta.title: How I got 100.000 views and 22.50$ revenue from 21 days on TikTok

title: I got over 100.000 views from posting about indie hacking 21 days on TikTok.
So that’s why I released my
50 customers before release
b
project.
Build a story. Build a project.
I was going to work on some projects.
The idea was simple: “Interview one new person every day about my Slapper idea. Try to get them onboard and pay 5$ to be a beta-tester. Get 50 people to say yes”.
You don’t earn money directly from TikTok.
The money I earned was
mostly symbolic
i
, but is possible to leverage better with a better strategy and products.
Because of that, I decided to add a paywall to restrict submissions. More on that in the end of this article.
Would the TikTok audience like hearing about techy topics?
I made
LarsList.org
a
http://larslist.org/
. A site that lists people named Lars.

This is a great thing to do both for business and social media. In business it is smart to talk to potential customers before building. In social media it is smart to have a system or a story to tell.

caption: A chart showing views over time
title: chart.png
But I felt I wanted to actually share some real work, and have some more consistency.
I started out with a video explaining my story.
The first video that I felt worked really well, was the one where I talk about the 🧠 brain computer.
In the end of the video I tell my followers that I am going to
make music
b
with my brain.
I think the reason this idea took off is that there actually are a lot of people named Lars in Norway, where I live!
Until this point, I mostly made random videos about programming, building on the web and things like that.
But you can earn money if you refer people
from
i
TikTok to your products.
What do you think about this way of communicating?
Let me know in the comments.
i
After this, the show was on. It was a huge leap out of my comfort zone.
The story behind this is that a lot of the people I interacted with daily was named “Lars”. I made this video as a joke, but it turned out to become pretty big.
The website got thousands of views and almost 200 Lars submissions.
I have never been very active on social media, and never exposed myself on video this way. This was truly an uncomfortable thing for me to do, especially in the beginning.
That seemed to be a genius system, because some of the best-performing videos I made were the videos I
didn’t want to post
i
The process of adding Larses was not automated so it was A LOT of work for me.
The Slapper.io journey (3000 views - multiple videos)
How did I get 💰 revenue from all of this?
I spent 21 days posting daily on TikTok about indie hacking and programming. The platform works differently than other platforms for sure.
My system was to post every day. No matter if it was going to be a low quality one, I was going to post it.
5.00$ x 3 =
b
- For my Slapper.io journey, I ask people to pay 5$ to be a beta tester. 3 people have paid.
I never figureed out how to do that, haha. Will need to look into that some time.
2.50$ x 3 =
b
- LarsList.org submissions. After a lot of manual work of adding Larses I added a paywall to restrict submissions. A few people paid to get added. That’s fun.
I recently started my TikTok project, where I post everyday about my indie hacking journey.
Now, 21 days after, I have over 100.000 views and 22.50$ revenue.
How I got 100.000 views and 22.50$ revenue from 21 days on TikTok
I think the audience and experience you earn on TikTok is way more valuable than the few short-time dollars you can squeeze out. But it is fun to earn a bit.

meta.description: I created the website that nobody asked for, but ended up changing the popularity of the name "Lars" forever.
meta.title: LarsList: How my app went viral on TikTok...and made $25

title: I created the website that nobody asked for, but ended up changing the popularity of the name "Lars" forever.
This is something we have to live with. I am proud of keeping the paywall, even when I have (at least) 3 haters.
Especially uncomfortable when it is something as silly as Lars List.
I knew there would be some negative reactions on the paywall.
b
Seems like I tapped into something.
b
And after some time, to my great surprise, I got this email:

caption: Google trends for Lars increased by 60%
title: googletrends.png
After some days – when the hype had died down a bit – I wanted to focus on other things and
not
i
be responsible for adding new Larses all the time. I had some alternatives:
The same way, it felt like many Larses liked the idea of this site. Perhaps by making Larses proud of their name?
Put it on TikTok for fun (it blew up)
Someone actually paid to be on my silly LarsList site!
From:
Click - the magic of instant connection
i
That’s 25$ in total. Not huge. But really fun.
And over the next weeks, some other submissions rolled in. I have gotten almost 10 paid LarsList submissions now.
I mean, no one would
pay
i
to be on the LarsList anyways, right? Quick way of not having to do any work. And if it turned out that people actually bought a submission, I would be happy to spend some time on it. A real
WIN-WIN situation
b
. Either they stopped submitting and I didn’t have to do work, OR they start paying and I become rich.
I should create a LarsList, a website where all Larses can be listed!
b
It all started one day when I was watching my messenger window. Suddenly I saw that the three top chats were all Larses. Crazy!
But now I’m wondering, should I do something more now? Or just leave this site floating in the void of the internet.
I envy people that can turn some viral moment into their benefit. That’s what I tried to do and
earned 25$
b
. Not too bad.
So being the genius procastinator I am, an idea popped into my head.
So I added a simple gumroad link to the submit button. It now cost 2.5$ to be submitted to the LarsList.
Usually my TikToks would get around 500 views. A good one would get 1000 views.
Nice! Fun! Haha, it gave me a good laugh. Someone actually paid to be on my silly LarsList site!
Most of the negative feedback were from TikTok comments:
This video had 5000 views in an hour. People were liking and sharing it like crazy.
Adding a paywall seemed like the absolute most fun option. I need to practice my “ask for money”-skill anyways (it can be uncomfortable), so why not.
“Having a similar name was certainly a significant factor that led them to connect.”
It is uncomfortable for me to ask for money. That’s why I am practicing it.
The next step (what to do with a community of 150 Larses?)
Do you have any ideas? Let me know in the comments!
i
People were submitting tons of Larses at the website. I got over 100 submissions the FIRST DAY. Submissions of Larses wanting to be on the LarsList. Crazy!
So, I went out and made a quick TikTok video. 15 seconds quickly explaining the site.
Google trends for Lars increased by 60%

I spent an evening or two, and hacked together LarsList.org. It was a simple site listing me and my three Larses. I also added a form where you could add yourself, if you are a Lars, but didn’t really think anyone would do it.
Seems like I also influenced the popularity of “Lars” in general.
It turned out that going through submissions and manually adding new Larses to the site was a hassle. Took a lot of time.
Will have a look at the birth statistics next year. Maybe we’ll see a spike in Lars-babies from 2020?
I want to tell about a quick website I made (LarsList.org) that became viral on TikTok. It made 25$. This is how it happened.
i
Google trends shows a 60% increase in search traffic for the word “Lars” when the video was released.
Ori Brafman writes about how
similarity
b
can influence how connected strangers feel with each other.
I mean, I have 150 emails. But not sure what to do with them.
… no one would pay to be on the LarsList anyways, right? Quick way of not having to do any work.
LarsList: How my app went viral on TikTok...and made $25
Maybe we’ll see a spike in Lars-babies from 2020?
